cleaned_text: | | k[ [szerkesztés](/w/index.php?title=F%C3%BCggel%C3%A9k:Sanskrit-English/k&action=edit§ion=1)] ka the first consonant of the alphabet, and the first guttural letter (corresponding in sound to k in keep or king) kra m. the letter or sound ka TPrt vat mfn. having the word ka NBD varga m. the gutturals (of which ka is the first letter) TPrt. Siddh. (cf. vargá.) ká kas, k, kim, interrog. pron. ( kim and 2. kad, and the. following words in which the interrogative base declension ka follows the pronoun tad except in nom. acc. sing. neut., where kim has taken the place of kad or kat in classical Sanskit but the old form kad is found in the Veda ( Gram. 227) ; [Zd. ka, kô, kâ, kat Gk. ?, ?, (Ion. ?, ?,) ?, ? ; Lat. quis, [240, 2] The interrogative sentence introduced by ka is often terminated by iti (e.g. kasya sa putra iti kathyatm, let it be said, 'whose son is he?'), but iti may be omitted and the sentence lose its direct interrogative character (e.g. kasya sa putro na jñyate, it is not known whose son he is). ka with or without 1. as may express 'how is it possible that?' 'what power have I, you, they, &c.?' (e.g. ke mama dhanvino'nye, what can the other archers do against me? ke vm paritrtum, what power have we to rescue you?) ka is often connected with a demonstrative pron. (e.g. ko'yam yti, who comes here?) or with the potential (e.g. ko hari nindet, who will blame Hari?) ka is sometimes repeated (e.g. ka ko'tra, who is there? kn kn, whom? whom? i.e. which of them? Gram. 54), and the repetition is often due to a kind of attraction (e.g. ke ki stram adhyayanyam, which book is to be read by whom? Gram. 836. a). When kim is connected with the inst. c. of a noun or with the indecl. participle it may express 'what is gained by doing so, &c.?' (= ko'rthas) [Page 240, Column 3] (e.g. ki vilambena, what is gained by delay? kim bahun, what is the use of more words? dhanena ki yo na dadti, what is the use of wealth to him who does not give? with inst. and gen., nruja kim auadhai, what is the use of medicine to the healthy?) ka is often followed by the particles iva, u, nma, nu, v, svid, some of which serve merely to generalize the interrogation (e.g. kim iva etad, what can this be? ka u ravat, who can possibly hear? ko nma jnti, who indeed knows? ko nv ayam, who, pray, is this? ki nu kryam, what is to be done? ko v devd anya, possibly other than a god? kasya svid hdaya nâsti, of what person is there no heart?) ka is occasionally used alone as an indefinite pronoun, especially in negative sentences (e.g. na kasya ko vallabha, no one is a favourite of any one nânyo jnti ka, no one else knows katha sa ghtayati kam, how does he kill any one?) Generally, however, ka is only made indefinite when connected with the particles ca, caná, cid, v, and ápi, in which case ka may sometimes be preceded by the relative ya (e.g. ye ke ca, any persons whatsoever yasyai kasyai ca devatyai, to any deity whatsoever yni kni ca mitri, any friends whatsoever yat kica, whatever). The particle cana, being composed of ca and na, properly gives a negative force to the pronoun (e.g. yasmd indrd te kicana, without which Indra there is nothing), but the negative sense is generally dropped (e.g. kacana, any one na kacana, no one), and a relative is sometimes connected with it (e.g. yat kicana, anything whatsoever). Examples of cid with the interrogative are common v and api are not so common, but the latter is often found in classical Sanskit (e.g. kacid, any one kecid, some na kacid, no one na kicid api, nothing whatsoever ya kacid, any one whatsoever kecit - kecit, some - others yasmin kasmin v dee, in any country whatsoever na ko'pi, no one na kimapi, nothing whatever). ka may sometimes be used, like 2. kad, at the beginning of a compound. ka-pya, &c ká m. Mn. vi, 67 Sur N. of a commentator on the Rmyaa katamá as, , at mfn. (superlative of 2. ka declined as a pronom., Gram. 236), who or which of many? (e.g. katamena path yts te, by which road have they gone?) it is often a mere strengthened substitute for ka, the superlative affix imparting emphasis hence it may occasionally be used for 'who or which of two?' (e.g. tayo katamasmai, to which of these two?) it may optionally be compounded with the word to which it refers (e.g. katama kaha, or katama-kaha, which Kaha out of many?) when followed by ca and preceded yatama an indefinite expression is formed equivalent to 'any whatsoever', &c. (e.g. yatamad eva katamac ca he may know anything whatsoever). In negative sentences katama with cana or katama with api = not even one, none at all (e.g. na katamaccanâha, not even on a single day, on no day at all) [Page 246, Column 3] in addition to the above uses katama is said to mean 'best', 'excessively good-looking' (cf. 3. ka) RV. &c katamôraga m. N. of a man katará as, , at mfn. (comparative of 2. ka declined as a pronom., Gram. 236), who or which of two? whether of two? Analogously to katama above katara may occasionally be used to express 'who or which of many?' (e.g. katarasy dii, in which quarter?), and may optionally be compounded with the word to which it refers (e.g. katara kaha or katara-kaha) in negative sentences katara with cana = neither of the two (e.g. na katara-cana jigye), neither of the two was conquered RV. &c. ; [Zd. katra Gk. ?, ? ; Eng. 3] whether ; Lat. uter ; Old Germ. huedar ; Slav. kotoryi.] tas ind. on which of the two sides? (fr. 2. ka), how? in katham mrâtmake tvayi vivsa, how can there be thee of murderous mind? katham utsjya tv gaccheyam, you? katham buddhv bhaviyati s, awakes? katham mtyu, prabhavati vedavidm, whence is it that death has power over those that know the Veda? katham avagamyate, whence is it inferred?) sometimes (e.g. katham tmna nivedaymi katha vâtmâpahra karomi, shall I declare myself or shall I withdraw?) katham is often found in connection with the particles iva, nma, nu, svid, which appear to generalize the interrogation (how possibly? how indeed? &c.) with nu it is sometimes = kimu, or kutas (e.g. katka nu, how much more! na katha nu, how much less!) katham is often connected, like kim, with the particles cana, cid, and api, which give an indefinite sense to the interrogative (e.g. katha cana, in any way, some how scarcely, with difficulty na katha cana, in no way at all kathacit, some how or other, by some means or other, in any way, with some difficulty, scarcely, in a moderate degree, a little na kathacit, not at all, in no way whatever na kathacid na, in no way not, i.e. most decidedly yath kathacit, in any way whatsoever kathacid yadi jvati, it is with difficulty that he lives katham api, some how or other, with some difficulty, scarcely a little katham api na, by no means, not at all) RV. &c according to lexicographers katham is a particle implying amazement surprise pleasure abuse katha (in comp. for katham at the beginning of an adjective compound it may also have the sense of kim) ruru m. L.), N. of an ancient city of great note (in the north-western provinces of India, situated on the kl nad, a branch of the Gag, in the modern district of Farrukhabad the popular spelling of the name presents, perhaps, greater variations than that of any place in ranks next to Ayodhy in Oude it is known in classical geography as Canogyza but the name applies also to its dependencies and the surrounding district the current etymology [kany, shortened to kanya, and kubja, 'round-shouldered or crooked'] refers to a legend in R. i, 32, 11 ff., relating to the hundred daughters of Kuanbha, the king of this city, who were all rendered crooked by Vyu for non-compliance with his licentious desires the ruins of the ancient city are said to occupy a site larger than that of London) MBh. (fr. 1. ki, originally nom. and acc. ká, kim is much used as a particle of interrogation like the Lat. num, an, sometimes translatable by 'whether?' but oftener serving only like a note of interrogation to mark a question (e.g. ki vydh vane'smin sacaranti, 'do hunters roam about in this wood?' In an interrogation the verb, if uncompounded with a preposition, generally retains its accent after kim P. 8-1, 44). To this sense may be referred the kim expressing inferiority, deficiency, &c. at the beginning of compounds (e.g. ki-rjan, what sort of king? i.e. a bad king P. 2-1, 64 ; v, 4, 70) also the kim prefixed to verbs with a similar meaning (e.g. kim-adh7te, he reads badly P. 8-1, 44 K.) kim-uta, or or kim-athav-uta, whether-or-or R. ak. Bhart. &c. (cf. utá.) kim is very frequently connected with particles, as follows: kím agá, wherefore then? RV atha kim, átha kim api, somewhat, to a considerable extent, rather, much more, still further ak. Megh. &c kim iti, why? ak. Kum. Pañcat. i. xvi, kím-u or much more? how much less? RV. Br. MBh. &c ki kila, what a pity! 146 ki-ca, moreover, further Pañcat. N. of Pith (daughter of a Ydava prince named ra or Vasu ariv. 5255, who gave her to his childless cousin Kunti or Kuntibhoja, by whom she was adopted she afterwards became one of the wives of Pu on one occasion before her marriage she paid such respect to the powerful sage Durvsas that he taught her an incantation or charm, by virtue of which she was to have a child by any god she liked to invoke out of curiosity she invoked the Sun, by whom she had a child, cf. kara but the Sun afterwards restored to her her maidenhood: soon after his marriage Pu retired to the woods to indulge his passion for hunting there he killed a male and female deer, who turned out to be a ishi and his wife in the form of these animals the sage cursed Pu and predicted that he would die in the embrace of one of his wives [Page 291, Column 2] hence Pu lived apart from Kunt, but with his approval she made use of her charm and had three sons, Yudhishhira, Bhma, and Arjuna, by the three deities Dharma, Vyu, and Indra respectively cf. mdr) P. Bhag. in the more recent he is deified, and is often represented as a young and amorous shepherd with flowing hair and a flute in his hand the following are a few particulars of his birth and history as related in Hariv. 3304 ff. and in the Puras &c.: Vasu-deva, who was a descendant of Yadu and Yayti, had two wives, Rohi and Devak the latter had eight sons of whom the eighth was Kisha Kasa, king of Mathur and cousin of Devak, was informed by a prediction that one of these sons would kill him he therefore kept Vasu-deva and his wife in confinement, and slew their first six children the seventh was Balarma who was saved by being abstracted from the womb of Devak and transferred to that of Rohi the eighth was Kisha who was born with black skin and a peculiar mark on his breast his father Vasu-deva managed to escape from Mathur with the child, and favoured by the gods found a herdsman named Nanda whose wife Yao-d had just been delivered of a son which Vasu-deva conveyed to Devak after substituting his own in its place. Nanda with his wife Yao-d took the infant Kisha and settled first in Gokula or Vraja, and afterwards in Vindvana, where Kisha and Bala-rma grew up together, roaming in the woods and joining in the sports of the herdsmen's sons [Page 306, Column 3] Kisha as a youth contested the sovereignty of Indra, and was victorious over that god, who descended from heaven to praise Kisha, and made him lord over the cattle [Hariv. 3787 ff. ; 7456 ff. VP.] Kisha [Hariv. 4078 ff. ; 8301 ff. VP. Gt.] of whom a thousand became his wives, though only eight are specified, Rdh being the favourite [Hariv. 6694 ff. ; 9177 ff. VP.] city called Dvrak in Gujart, and thither transported the inhabitants of Mathur after killing Kasa Kisha had various wives besides the Gops, and by Rukmi had a son Pradyumna who is usually identified with Kma-deva with Jains, Kisha is one of the nine black Vasu-devas with Buddhists he is the chief of the black demons, who are the enemies of Buddha and the white demons) N. of an attendant in Skanda's retinue MBh. ix, 2559 of an Asura Hariv. 12936 Sy. on RV. i, 101, 1 of a king of the Ngas MBh. ii, 360 Divyâv. ii of Arjuna (the most renowned of the Pu princes, so named apparently from his colour as a child) MBh. iv, 1389 of Vysa MBh.
